metadata.title: Infectious bronchitis virus attaches to lipid rafts and enters cells via clathrin mediated endocytosis

body_text.text: However, the molecular mechanisms involved in IBV entry are not well characterized. 23 In this study, systematic approaches were used to dissect IBV entry process in various 24 susceptible cells. First, we observed that lipid rafts were involved in IBV attachment. 25 Second, low pH in intracyplasmic vesicles was required for virus entry. By using the 26 specific clathrin mediated endocytosis (CME) inhibitor or knock down of clathrin 27 heavy chain (CHC), we demonstrated that IBV mainly utilized the CME for its 28 entry. Furthermore, GTPase dynamin1 was involved in virus containing vesicle 29 scission and internalization. Surprisingly, CME adaptor Eps15 had no effect on IBV (44); however, the endocytic pathway that IBV hijacks is unclear. 135 The early step in the entry process of IBV into target cells is initiated by 136 engagement of the S glycoprotein with the receptor. Here, using several cell lines 137 permissive to IBV Beaudette strain, we report that IBV virion attaches to lipid rafts in 138 the cell surface and the efficient entry of IBV into cells requires the presence of intact 139 lipid rafts. We also address IBV entry pathway by systematically perturbing the Anti-VSV G (Ab50549) was obtained from Abcam (UK in Table 3 . Densitometry. The intensities of corresponding bands were quantified using ImageJ 341 program (NIH).

IBV entry is lipid raft-associated. MβCD was used to disrupt lipid rafts. The subtoxic dose of the MβCD in IBV It should be mentioned that the receptor of IBV entry is controversial. Whereas 387 some work states that heparan sulfate is a selective attachment factor for the IBV
Beaudette strain (48), another report concludes that sialic acid is a receptor
Several pH-dependent endocytic pathways are used by various viruses, including 444 CME, CavME, macropinocytosis, and clathrin/caveolin-independent endocytosis (55).

To identify the endocytic pathway employed by IBV, pharmacological inhibition, 446 siRNA-mediated depletion, and overexpression of dominant negative or constitutive 447 active proteins were carried out to block or strengthen respective endocytic pathway.

First, we investigated the effect on IBV entry by diverse pharmacological drugs 449 treatments which have been well known to inhibit CME, CavME, or 450 macropinocytosis. Vero, H1299, and DF-1 cells were exposed to increasing The release of progeny virus particle was also determined by TCID 50 . Results in Fig.

6C showed that expression of dynamin1-DN significantly reduced progeny virus 517 production by around 0.5-fold, but dynamin1-WT, Eps15-WT, and Eps15-DN had no 518 significant effect on this, compared to those in GFP expressing cells. In all, above 519 results suggest that IBV entry depends on functional dynamin1, but not Eps15. Eps15 depletion inhibited VSV G expression (Fig. 7D ), IBV N protein expression was 529 unchanged by this knock down (Fig. 7C ). These data further confirmed although IBV 530 entry is dependent on CME, Eps15 is not required. Furthermore, knock down of 531 dynamin1 (by 92%) was accompanied by a significant reduction of the amount of 532 incoming IBV gRNA (by 48%) and IBV protein expression (by 71%) (Fig. 7E-G) .
Collectively, these results indicate that dynamin1, but not Eps15, is functionally 534 required for IBV entry.

As IBV co-localized extensively with endo-lysosomal compartments, we asked 634 whether all these vehicles are really involved in IBV infectious route. To achieve this, 635 we took advantage of the fact that, in addition to providing organelle identity, Rab5 IBV infection (Fig. 9B) . These data reveal that IBV could not infect cells expressing inhibited VSV infection (Fig. 9D) . Collectively, these data indicate that major IBV 658 virions are delivered to early endosomes after CME, followed by transferring to late 659 endosomes.
Knock down of Rab5 or Rab7 was carried out to confirm above conclusion.
H1299 cells were transfected with siRab5 or siRab7, followed with IBV infection.

The knock down effect of Rabs and IBV N protein expression was examined by 663 Western blot. Fig. 9E (Fig. 9J) . Altogether, these data further confirm that after internalized by 673 CME, both early and late endosomes are required for IBV transport. implying that IBV membranes undergo fusion with late endosome/lysosome 696 membranes at 3 h.p.i. or between 2-3 h.p.i.. We also performed above fusion 697 experiment by using well studied VSV labeled with R18/DiOC as control, which has 698 been reported to fuse with early endosomes. As shown in Supplementary Fig.4

Our results so far demonstrate that IBV pass through early and late endosomes. increased the expression of IBV N by 1.45-fold (Fig. 11A) , however, the virus 720 internalization was not increased (Fig. 11B) , indicating VCP plays a role 721 post-internalization. The higher rate of viral gRNA replication associated with VCP 722 expression was also detected with RT-PCR by using primers targeting to negative 723 stranded gRNA (Fig. 11C) . Immunofluorescence in Fig.11D showed that GFP-VCP further confirm our observations, we used inhibitor CPZ to interfere with CME, or 798 knock down of CHC siRNA to specifically block CME, and we found that IBV 799 internalization and gene expression were significantly decreased. This evidence 800 determines the importance of CME in IBV entry, which is widely hijacked by various 801 envelope viruses. Moreover, the importance of dynamin1, a GTPase that helps to snap 802 the vesicle from plasma membrane, was determined during IBV entry. Lipid rafts is 803 often considered to be involved in CavME. To explain these contradictory with late endosome-lysosome membrane, releases genome in to cytoplasm (Fig. 12) . Images were acquired by LSM880 confocal laser-scanning microscope (Zeiss).

FIGREF0.text: 30 internalization. Third, the penetration of IBV into cells led to active cytoskeleton 31 rearrangement. After internalization, virus particles moved along with the classical 32 endosome/lysosome track, as evidenced by co-localization of R18 labeled IBV with 33 vehicle markers Rab5/Rab7/LAMP1 along with the infection time course. Functional 34 inactivation of Rab5 and Rab7 significantly inhibited IBV infection. VCP, a protein 35 helps early endosome maturation, was involved virus trafficking. Finally, by using the 36 dual R18/DiOC labeled IBV, we observed that membrane fusion with late 37 endosome/lysosome membranes was induced between 2-3 h.p.i.. Taken together, our 38 findings demonstrate that IBV virions attach to lipid rafts and are internalized into 39 cells via CME, move along with early/late endosomes-lysosomes, finally fuse 40 with late endosome-lysosome membranes, release virus genome into cytoplasm. This 41 study provides comprehensive images of IBV attachment-internalization-trafficking 6

FIGREF1.text: 140 function of key factors in the various endocytic mechanisms using chemical inhibitors, 141 siRNA silence, and overexpression of dominant negative proteins. To achieve a 142 successful tracking of virion attachment, entry, intracellular trafficking, and 143 membrane fusion, octadecyl rhodamine (R18) and 3, 3'-Dihexyloxacarbocyanine 144 Iodide (DiOC) were labeled on viral membrane as fluorescent tags.145Immunofluorescence analysis was used to visualize the co-localization or 146 co-trafficking of virus and cellular factors. Our results reveal that IBV is internalized 147 into cells by CME, transports along early endosomes, late endosomes, and fuses with 148 membrane at late endosome-lysosomes.149MATERIALS AND METHODS150 Cells and viruses. Vero cells, Huh7 cells, BHK-21, and DF-1 cells were maintained 151 in Dulbecco's modified Eagle medium (DMEM) with 4500 mg/l glucose, 152 supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) (Hyclone, USA), 100 units/ml 153 penicillin and 100 μg/ml streptomycin (Invitrogen, USA). H1299 cells were 154 maintained in RPMI 1640, supplemented with 10% FBS in the presence of penicillin 155 and streptomycin. Above cells were purchased from ATCC (USA) and cultured at 156 37℃ with 5% CO 2 . 157 The Beaudette strain of IBV (ATCC VR-22) adapted to Vero cells was used in 158 this study. As a well characterized virus, Vesicular Stomatitis Virus (VSV) was used 159 as control virus. Virus stock was prepared by infecting monolayers of Vero cells with 160 multiplicity of infection (MOI) of 0.1 in FBS free DMEM. After attachment for 1 161 hour (h), the unbounded virus was removed and replaced with FBS free DMEM. The 162 virus and cells were incubated at 37℃ until 100% cells were with cytopathic effect 163 (CPE). After freezing and thawing the virus containing liquid for three times, cell 164 debris was removed by centrifugation at 3000×rpm, and supernatant was aliquoted 165 and stored at −80℃ as virus stock. A control of Vero cell lysates from mock-infected 166 cells was prepared in the same manner. The virus yield was assessed by titration on 167 Vero cells in 96-well plates according to the method described by Reed and 168 Muench(45). 169 R18 and R18/DiOC labeling of IBV or VSV. Vero cells were infected with 0.1 170 MOI of virus until 100% cells were with CPE. The cell supernatant was clarified by 171 centrifuged at 4000×g for 15 min. The supernatant was then centrifuged at 5000×g for 172 60 min and concentrated by 100-fold by using Amicon® Ultra-15 Centrifugal Filter 173 Devices (10-kDa cutoff, Merk, Poland) which provided fast ultrafiltration. Mock 174 infected Vero cells culture medium was concentrated in the same manner as control 175 sample in labeling experiment. 176 R18 labeling was prepared as described previously (44): 100 μl of concentrated 177 virus or control sample was incubated with 2.5 μl of 1.7 mM R18 (Molecular Probes, 178 USA) on a rotary shaker for 1 h at room temperature (in the dark). R18/DiOC labeling 179 was prepared as described (46): 100 μl of concentrated virus or control sample was 180 incubated with 3.3 mM DiOC (Molecular Probes, USA) and 6.7 mM R18 mixture 181 (Molecular Probes, USA) with gentle shaking for 1 h at room temperature. After 182 finishing labeling, the virus and dye mixture was re-suspended in 8 ml 183 phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and the excess dye was removed with an Amicon® 184 Ultra-15 Centrifugal Filter Devices (10-kDa cutoff, Merk, Poland) by centrifugation 185 for 60 min. Finally, 100 μl of R18 or R18/DiOC labeled-virus were obtained.

FIGREF2.text: Inhibitors and antibodies. The endocytotic pathway inhibitors Amiloride (S1811),187 Nystatin (S1934), and chlorpromazine (CPZ, S2456) were purchased from Selleck 188 (USA). Actin monomer-sequestering drug cytochalasin D (CytoD, PHZ1063), Soluble (C4951) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich (USA). 193 Anti-IBV S and N antibodies were obtained through immunization of rabbits 194 with respective antigens. Anti-flotillin-1 (#18634), anti-GFP (#2956), anti-CHC 195 (clathrin heavy chain) (#4769s), anti-Rab5 (#3547s), anti-Rab7 (#9367s), and 196 anti-LAMP1 (#9091s) were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (USA).

FIGREF4.text: All data are presented as means ±standard deviations (SD), as 336 indicated. Student's t test was used to compare data from pairs of treated or untreated 337 groups. Statistical significance is indicated in the figure legends. All statistical 338 analyses and calculations were performed by using Graph Pad Prism 5 (Graph Pad 339 Software Inc., La Jolla, CA).

FIGREF6.text: permissive cell lines was determined by a cell proliferation assay (Supplementary Fig. 352 1). After determination of subtoxic dose, Vero, H1299, Huh7 cells were treated with 5 353 mM MβCD for 30 min at pre-, during-, or post-IBV infection at -0.5, 0, 1, 2 h.p.i. 354 (Fig. 1A). The effect of MβCD on virus infection was accessed by checking viral 355 treatment of various cells with MβCD at -1.5 and 0 h.p.i. acquired maximum blockage 358 of virus genome level, which was determined by checking negative stranded genomic 359 RNA at 4 h.p.i.. Surprisingly, treatment with MβCD at 1 and 2 h.p.i. did not affect the 360 virus genome production. Next, viral N protein expression was analyzed with Western 361 blot at 8 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 1C, 1F, 1I, treatment with MβCD -1.5 and 0 h.p.i. 362 obtained maximum inhibition effect on viral N protein expression in various cell lines, 363 whereas treatment with MβCD at post-entry step did not affect the viral N protein 364 expression. In consistence, the progeny virus release was also inhibited by MβCD 365 treatment at -1.5 and 0 h.p.i., but not by post-entry treatment (Fig. 1D, 1G, 1J). In all, 366 above data demonstrate that MβCD inhibits virus entry step, but not post-entry 367 process, suggesting that intact lipid rafts are required for virus attachment and/or 368 entry. 369 To confirm whether the effect of the MβCD on virus entry was due to cholesterol 370 depletion, we examined the effect of exogenous cholesterol replenishment on virus 371 entry after MβCD treatment. Vero, H1299, and Huh7 cells were pretreated with 2.5 or 372 5 mM MβCD for 30 min, supplemented with/without exogenous 1 mM cholesterol for 373 1 h, followed with IBV infection. The incoming virus gRNA, the expression of IBV N 374 protein, and the progeny virus particles in the culture medium, were examined. The 375 incoming virus gRNA was examined with semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR at 2 376 h.p.i.. Results in Fig. 2A, 2D, 2G showed that MβCD treatment reduced virus gRNA 377 internalization, however, cholesterol replenishment restored virus entry. Accordingly, 378 virus protein expression was determined with Western blot at 8 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 379 2B, 2E, and 2H, compared to that in control treatment cells, viral N protein expression 380 was reduced by MβCD treatment and was restored in cholesterol replenishment cells.381In accordance, progeny virus release at 12 h.p.i. was rescued by cholesterol 382 replenishment, as determined by TCID 50 assay(Fig. 2C, 2F, 2I). Above results suggest 383 that IBV attachment and/or entry really depends on intact lipid rafts in various cell 384 lines.

FIGREF7.text: determinant of infection (49). Since membrane cholesterol plays an important role in 390 early infection stages, the interaction of IBV with its receptor may occur in lipid rafts.391To test this hypothesis, Vero cells were incubated with IBV for 1 h at 4℃ and lipid392 rafts were isolated by a sucrose flotation gradient. The individual fractions were 393 analyzed for the presence of rafts marker flotillin-1, IBV N protein, and IBV S protein 394 by Western blotting. In IBV-infected cells, we found that S protein and N protein were 395 co-localized with the rafts marker flotillin-1in fractions 2 and 3 (Fig. 3A). Thus, the 396 biochemical fractionation analysis suggests the association of IBV with lipid rafts 397 during attachment. 398 To directly observe the binding of virus particles to cell surface lipid rafts, IBV 399 particles were concentrated and labeled with the lipophilic fluorescent dye R18. The 400 cell culture supernatant was concentrated and mixed with R18 as mock group. Such 401 R18 labeled virus retained high levels of infectivity (Fig. 3B). Immunofluoresence 402 was then performed to check the interaction between R18-IBV and lipid rafts marker 403 GM1. Vero cells were incubated with either mock or R18-IBV, and CTB-FITC (binds 404 to lipid rafts marker GM1) at 4℃ for 1 h, followed with DAPI staining of nucleus. As 405 shown in Fig. 3C, the mock infected cells displayed no R18 red signal, while the 406 R18-IBV infected cells displayed red dot signal on the plasma membrane, and 407 co-localized with CTB-FITC, which represents the outline of lipid rafts. This result 408 confirms the association of IBV with lipid rafts on cell surface.

FIGREF8.text: concentrations of Chlorpromazine (CPZ), an inhibitor of clathrin lattice 452 polymerization (56), Amiloride, a specific inhibitor of Na + /H + exchanger activity 453 important for macropinosome formation(17, 23, 57, 58), or Nystatin, a CavME 454 inhibitor (59). Virus endocytosis was quantified by measuring the amount of 455 intracellular viral gRNA at 2 h.p.i., and virus replication was scored by IBV N protein 456 expression level at 8 h.p.i.. The toxicity of each inhibitor was carefully determined 457 (data not shown). As semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR results shown in Fig. 5A, 5C, 458 and 5E, compared to the control group, pretreatment of cells with CME inhibitor CPZ 459 strongly inhibited the internalization of viral gRNA in Vero, H1299, and DF-1 cells, 460 which is dose dependent; however, Amiloride pretreatment did not significantly 461 change the internalization of virus in all three cell lines. Nystatin pretreatment did not 462 alter the virus internalization in either Vero or DF-1 cells; however, it slightly reduced 463 the internalization in H1299 cells. Western blot detection of viral N protein expression 464 in Fig. 5B, 5D, and 5F showed that CPZ significantly inhibited the viral N protein 465 expression in a dose dependent manner; Amiloride pretreatment did not significantly 466 change the expression of N protein in all three cell lines. In Nystatin pretreated Vero 467 cells, IBV N protein remained in a steady level, compared to control treated cells; 468 however, in H1299 and DF-1 cells, Nystatin pretreatment slightly reduced the viral 469 protein expression. It has been reported that VSV entry is mediated by CME, and 470 indeed, CPZ pretreatment of Vero cells reduced the VSV G protein expression in a dose dependent manner, while Amiloride and Nystatin pretreatment had no effect (Fig. 472 5I

FIGREF9.text: cells were not chosen for the protein expression experiment due to their low 499 GFP-Eps15-DN, dynamin1-WT, and dynamin1-DN was detected in Fig. 6A (low 501 panel), and the expression level of Eps15 is lower than dynamin1. Compared to that in 502 GFP expressing cells, the expression of IBV N protein was increased in 503 dynamin1-WT expressing cell, whereas reduced in dynamin1-DN expressing cells, 504 demonstrating the crucial role of dynamin1 in IBV infection. Surprisingly, neither 505 Eps15-WT nor Eps15-DN changed the expression level of IBV N, due to unknown 506 reason. It has been reported that VSV entry relies on functional Eps15 (67), thus, the 507 effect of Eps15 on VSV entry of Vero cells was also examined as control experiment.508 Eps15-DN indeed inhibited VSV infectivity, as evidenced by the reduced level of 509 VSV G protein (by 0.66-fold) in Eps15-DN expressing cells (Fig. 6D). Therefore, the 510 failure of blocking IBV infectivity by Eps15-DN is not due to low expression level of 511 Eps15-DN or experimental error. To confirm above result, the internalization of IBV 512 gRNA was quantified at 2 h.p.i.. As shown in Fig. 6B, expression of dynamin1-DN 513 significantly blocked virus internalization by 0.6-fold, whereas expression of 514 dynamin1-WT, Eps15-WT, and Eps15-DN had no significant effect on virus entry.515

FIGREF10.text: To further confirm above conclusion, we analyzed the effect of Eps15 and 521 dynamin1 depletion on IBV uptake. To this purpose, cells were transfected with 522 siRNA targeting to either Eps15 or dynamin1, and then infected with IBV (H1299 523 cells) or us VSV (Vero cells) . The knock down efficiency of Eps15 or dynamin1 and 524 intracellular IBV gRNA were measured by semi-quantitative real time RT-PCR. As 525 shown inFig. 7, successful silence of Eps15 mRNA was obtained by siEps15 in both 526 H1299 and Vero cells(Fig. 7A, C); however, silence of Eps15 expression had no 527 significant effect on the IBV gRNA internalization(Fig. 7B). Moreover, although

FIGREF11.text: We further analyzed the effect of silencing CHC expression on IBV uptake and536 infection. To this purpose, cells were transfected with siRNA targeting CHC and then 537 infected with IBV (H1299 cells) or VSV (Vero cells). As shown in Fig. 7H-J, 538 depletion of CHC was accompanied by a significant reduction of IBV gRNA 539 internalization and IBV/VSV protein expression, which further demonstrates a 540 functional clathrin pathway is required for efficient IBV infection. 541 IBV entry leads to active actin rearrangement. 542 In Saccharomyces cerevisae, clathrin-coated patches on the cell surface mature 543 into ∼200 nm tubular invaginations with coat proteins at their tip. The actin 544 cytoskeleton machinery is recruited after coat formation and provides an essential 545 force for membrane deformation and internalization (69). Recent studies have 546 revealed that the rhabdoviruses (70), VSV (7), RABV (71), and IHNV (72) are 547 internalized through CME and depend on actin. Although we have demonstrated that 548 IBV enter cells by hijacking clathrin dependent route, it is unclear whether actin 549 filaments are involved in IBV uptake. To examine the role of actin filaments in IBV 550 entry, we first examined the actin polymerization during IBV internalization. Vero 551 cells were incubated with IBV at 4℃ for 1 h, and the temperature was shifted to 37℃.552 Actin filaments were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-phalloidin (green) and IBV N 553 antibody at 15 min time interval and were observed by confocal microscopy. In 554 mock-infected cells, the actin stress fibers were visible clearly. At 15 to 45 min.p.i., 555 the number of actin stress fibers dramatically decreased, the cells rounded up, and 21 cells surface displayed significant blebbing. The cell morphology and actin 557 distribution returned to normal at 60 min.p.i. (Fig. 8A). Above observation indicates 558 that IBV infection results in transient actin de-polymerization and re-arrangement. 559 IBV N protein antibody is not sensitive enough to detect the incoming virus. To check 560 whether of IBV internalization associates with actin, R18-IBV was applied to Vero 561 cell. Actin filaments were stained with Alexa Fluor 488-phalloidin at 15 min time 562 interval, and the red signal of R18-IBV and green signal of actin were observed. As 563 expected, images in Fig. 8B showed that there was no R18 red signal in mock 564 infection group. In the R18-IBV infection group, R18-IBV was detected at cell 565 surface at 0 min, displayed as red signal. After attachment, R18-IBV entered cells and 566 co-localized well with actin at 15, 30, and 45 min, shown as yellow signal. At 60 min, 567 Most R18-IBV particles separated with actin, displayed as red signal again. This 568 observation suggests that IBV enters cells via actin cytoskeleton. Here, we also 569 incubated the well characterized R18-VSV with Vero cells as control group. As 570 R18-VSV enters into cells quickly, we chose the time interval of 5 min. Image in 571 Supplementary Fig. 2A showed that R18-VSV also caused actin fiber 572 de-polymerization and cell rounded up at 5-30 min.p.i.. The cell morphology and 573 actin distribution returned to normal at 30 min. Meanwhile, R18-VSV co-localized 574 well with actin at 5, 10, 20, and 30 min, suggesting that VSV also moves along actin 575 fiber after internalization, consistent with previous report (73).576 We further investigated the role of the actin cytoskeleton in IBV entry by using 577 chemical inhibitors to interfere with actin polymerization or de-polymerization. Vero 578 cells were treated with jasplakinolide (Jas), an actin polymer-stabilizing drug (74-76), 579 or with cytochalasm D (CytoD), which binds to the growing ends of actin filaments 580 and prevents the polymerization (77). Vero cells were pretreated with either Jas or 581 CytoD in increasing concentrations before being infected with IBV. Cells were 582 harvested at indicated time points to measure IBV gRNA internalization or N 583 protein expression. Fig. 8C-D showed that when actin polymers were stabilized by Jas, 584 the IBV internalization and N protein expression were increased in a dose-dependent 585 manner. Fig. 8E-F showed that when CytoD prevented the formation of actin 586 polymers, IBV internalization and N protein expression were also significantly 587 increased. This observation is self-contradictory and out of expectation. Thus, we use 588 the well characterized VSV as control to perform this experiment, ensuring the 589 inhibitors work. When the Jas or CytoD was applied to Vero cells before VSV 590 infection, both inhibitors reduced VSV G protein expression (Supplementary Fig. 2B, 591 C), consistent with previous report of actin dependent entry of VSV (73). These 592 results imply that the inhibitors indeed interfere with actin polymerization or 593 de-polymerization. The enhancement of IBV infection by these inhibitors is not the 594 only case, it has been reported that SFV infection was also enhanced by CytoD 595 pretreatment (78). In all, above results demonstrate that the binding of IBV to cell 596 surface causes actin de-polymerization and rearrangement, however, when the actin 597 de-polymerization and rearrangement are interfered by inhibitors, the virus entry is 598 enhanced. How do the inhibitors increase IBV entry? The underlying mechanisms are 599 unclear. 600 IBV moves across the entire endo-lysosomal system. 601 After identification of the endocytic pathway hijacked by IBV, we next tracked 602 the transport vesicles utilized by incoming IBV. R18-IBV was incubated with Vero 603 cells

Accordingly, dominant negative mutant of these proteins has been shown 638 to block cargo transport (83, 84). Expression of Rab5-DN prevents fusion of 639 endocytic vesicles with early endosomes, while Rab7-DN prevents movement from 640 early to late endosomes. The cells were harvested for Western blot to check the expression of Rabs and 644 IBV N protein. To further verify above observation, we quantified the 652 internalized IBV in Rabs expressing cells. Results in Fig. 9C confirmed that 653 expression of Rab5-DN and Rab7-DN decreased internalization of IBV gRNA by 654 0.6-fold. Moreover, expression of Rab7-CA slightly increased virus internalization. 655 To ensure our Rabs construct was functional, we examine the effect of Rabs on VSV 656 infection in Vero cells. As shown previously (73), Rab5-DN, but not Rab7-DN,657

FIGREF14.text: 674IBV fuses with late endosomes or lysosomes675    To understand the fusion of IBV envelope with cellular membranes, we labeled 676 IBV virion with two fluorescent lipids, R18 (red) and DiOC (green), a labeling677 method developed by Sakai and coworkers (85). The intact virus membrane displays 678 the red color as the high concentration of R18 quenches the fluorescence signal 679 emitted by the DiOC. When the virus membrane fuses with cellular membrane, the 680 two lipids were diluted and the green fluorescence of DiOC was no longer quenched 681 by R18, red and green color will be displayed respectively. The Vero cell culture 682 supernatant was labeled with R18 and DiOC as mock infection sample. Vero cells 683 were infected with R18/DiOC-IBV or with R18/DiOC-mock for 1, 2, 3 h, stained with 684 Rab5, Rab7, LAMP1 antibodies, and observed under confocal microscope. As shown 685 in Fig. 10, in mock infection group, there was neither red signal nor green signal 686 observed (first panel). When the R18/DiOC labeled virus was incubated with cells, 687 only red color spots were observed at 1 and 2 h.p.i., no green signals were detected at 688 these two time points (second and third panels). Moreover, most of the red spots were 689 co-localized with early endosomes marker Rab5 at 1 h.p.i. (pink spots with white 690 arrows in second panel), and transferred to Rab7 containing late endosomes or 691 LAMP1 containing lysosomes at 2 h.p.i. (pink spots with white arrows in third panel). 692 Gradually, green spots (membrane fusion signals) were observed and increased in 693 numbers at 3 h.p.i. (white arrow in fourth panel), overlapped with either late 694 endosome marker Rab7 or lysosome marker LAMP1 (white arrows in fourth panel),695

FIGREF15.text: Thus, maturation of endosome should provide the environmental cues required for708 productive virus-cell fusion. VCP is an abundant protein implicated in an increasing 709 number of biological processes, including membrane fusion after mitosis (86), retro-710 translocation of unfolded proteins from the endoplasmic reticulum (87, 88), spindle 711 assembly (89), and endosome trafficking (90, 91). Previous report shows that 712 depletion of VCP results in an accumulation of virus particles in the early endosomal 713 compartments, suggesting that VCP is required for the maturation of endosomes and 714 efficient transfer of virus particles from the early to late endosomes (92). To further 715 access the role of VCP in IBV infection, we constructed GFP-tagged VCP and 716 transiently expressed this protein in H1299 cells, followed with infection. The 717 expression of GFP-VCP was confirmed by Western blot (Fig. 11A). Compared with 718 the GFP expressing control group, overexpression of GFP-VCP significantly 719

FIGREF16.text: was co-localized with Rab5 (yellow in second panel), instead of Rab7 or LAMP1,725    suggesting the role of VCP in early endosome maturation. Taken together, these 726 results demonstrate that VCP is involved in transferring IBV from early endosomes to 727 destination for efficient replication.728 DISCUSSION 729 Viruses must enter the host cell to start their life cycle. Thus, characterization of 730 viral entry pathway is important for understanding of virus pathogenesis and design of 731 anti-viral drugs. Envelope viruses penetrate cells by two different ways: fusion with 732 cell plasma membrane or receptor-mediated endocytosis. Direct membrane fusion on 733 the cell surface is independent of low pH, and access through the endocytosis pathway 734 usually relies on the low pH of the endocytic vesicles. Different endocytosis pathways 735 have been characterized over the past decade, in which the CME is one of the most 736 commonly used by many envelope viruses (93). Coronavirus entry is mediated by S 737 protein, which is responsible for receptor binding and membrane fusion. Previously, it 738 has been demonstrated that SARS-CoV is internalized by CME in human hepatoma 739 HepG2 cell line (39), however, in HEK293E-ACE2-GFP cells, the entry of 740 SARS-CoV is clathrin-and caveolae-independent (40); MHV entry is mediated by 741 CME through the endo-/lysosomal pathway in proteolysis-dependent manner (43, 742 94-97); PHEV enters into cells via CME in Rab5, cholesterol, and low pH 743 dependent manner (98); HCoV-NL63 requires CME for successful entry into the 744 LLC-MK2 cells (99); for the HCoV-229E, a CavME uptake has been suggested (16), 745 however, the clinical isolates of HCoV-229E bypass the endosome for cell entry (100

FIGREF17.text: Lipid rafts are involved in regulation of different biological events, serve as 757 organizing centers of signaling molecules assembly, and influence membrane fluidity758    and membrane protein trafficking (101). The involvement of lipid rafts in virus entry,759    assembly and budding has been demonstrated by either the co-localization study of760 the viral structural proteins and lipid rafts or the effects of lipid rafts disrupting agents 761 on the replication processes of several viruses (102). The best characterized lipid 762 rafts-related non-enveloped viral entry is simian virus 40 (SV40) and echovirus type 1 763 (EV1) (103, 104). Binding of SV40 with MHC class I receptors triggers receptor 764 clustering and redistribution, more caveolae is recruited from the cytoplasm at the site 765 of entry, resulting in caveolae-mediated endocytosis in about 20 min (104). In some 766 cell types, SV40 can enter the caveosomes directly from lipid rafts in non-coated 767 vesicles (105). Similar to SV40, EV1 attachment and binding with cells triggers 768 clustering and relocation of α2β1-integrin receptors from lipid rafts to the 769 caveolae-like structures (104). Depletion of cholesterol in lipid rafts inhibits EV1 770 infection (103). For envelope virus, Semliki Forest virus (SFV) and Sindbis virus 771 (SIN) require cholesterol and sphingolipids in target membrane lipid rafts for 772 envelope glycoprotein-mediated membrane fusion and entry (29). Many envelope 773 virus receptors are located in lipid rafts or would be relocated into lipid rafts after 774 infection, such as Human T-lymphotropic virus Type I (HTLV-1) receptor glucose 775 transporter 1 (GLUT-1), Ebola virus and Marburg virus folate receptor-α (FRα), 776 Hepatitis B virus complement receptor type 2 (CR2), Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) 777 receptor CD46 (106). An alternative receptor for Human Immunodeficiency virus 778 (HIV-1) envelope glycoprotein on epithelial cells is glycosphingolipid 779 galactosyl-ceramide (GalCer), which also enriches at lipid rafts (107, 108). Membrane 780 cholesterol is also involved in the first stages of flavivirus infection (47, 109). Guo et 781 al demonstrate that IBV structural proteins, but not non-structural proteins, migrate 782 and integrate into lipid rafts after viral protein translation. The cholesterol enriched 783 microdomains were only involved in IBV attachment, not virus replication or virus 784 particle release (38). However, the involvement mechanisms of lipid rafts on IBV 785 infectivity are still unclear. In our study, we substantiated the involvement of lipid 786 rafts on virus life cycle via disruption of lipid rafts by using chemicals at pre-, during-, 787 or post-infection, and checked IBV internalization, viral protein expression, and 788 progeny virus release. Results showed that lipid rafts were involved in IBV entry step. 789 Cholesterol replenishment experiment further confirmed that lipid rafts were 790 necessary for IBV entry. Membrane flotation assay showed the co-fractionation of 791 IBV particles and lipid rafts during absorption step. Immunofluoresence showed that 792 R18-IBV associates with lipid rafts on the cells surface. Above evidence substantiates 793 that IBV initiates the entry step by attaching to lipid rafts. 794 Further experiment showed that chemical inhibitor of endosome acidification 795 (NH 4 Cl) treatment in various susceptible cells reduced the IBV internalization and 796 protein expression, suggesting a requirement for transport of virions to endosomes. To797

FIGREF18.text: observations, Huh7, a caveolin deficient cell line (110, 111), was used in the 805 cholesterol depletion experiment. When cholesterol was depleted by chemicals or 806 replenished in Huh7 cells, similar inhibition effect on IBV entry was observed as that 807 in Vero and H1299 cells. These results confirm that although IBV attachment and 808 entry depend on the intact lipid rafts, CME is the main endocytotic pathway for 809 internalization.

FIGREF19.text: Our final research question was the virus trafficking route. By using R18-labeled 811 IBV to infect cells, we found that IBV attachment leads to actin rearrangement and812 co-localized with actin filament after internalization. This indicates that virus 813 internalization requires the actin de-polymerization or polymerization, to facilitate the 814 virus containing vesicles to move along actin filament. However, stabilization of the 815 actin filament using Jas and inhibition of actin polymerization using CytoD resulted in 816 increase of virus entry. Rab5 and Rab7 GTPases are the key regulators of transport to 817 early and late endosomes, and ablation of Rab5 and Rab7 has been widely used to 818 study viral entry. Using R18-labeled virus, we found that after internalization, 819 incoming IBV particles were first co-localized with Rab5 and then with Rab7, finally 820 overlapped with lysosome marker LAMP1, across the entire endocytic network. The 821 importance of Rab proteins were examined by overexpression and RNA interference 822 technology. The results showed that Rab5 and Rab7 played crucial roles for IBV entry, 823 confirming that IBV trafficking really depends on early and late endosomes. Also, 824 using the R18 and DiOC double labeled virus, we revealed that the membrane fusion 825 happens at 2-3 h.p.i., the time point of virus reaches late endosome-lysosome. 826 Overexpression of VCP, a protein involved in endosome maturation, increased virus 827 gene expression. We speculated that IBV particles were first transported to early 828 endosomes in Rab5-demepdent manner, and were guided to late endosomes in Rab7 829 and VCP dependent manner. Also, the Rab7 dependence indicates that membrane 830 fusion depends on endosomal maturation, suggesting that low pH environment in the 831 late endosome-lysosome may provide an important signal for fusion and viral gRNA 832 release.833In conclusion, we conduct a systematic study to dissect IBV entry process in 834 susceptible cell lines. The evidence presented here indicates that IBV attaches to lipid 835 rafts, induces actin de-polymerization, internalizes into clathrin coated vesicles via 836 dynamin1 snapping, transports along early/late endosome, and lysosome, finally fuses 837

FIGREF20.text: An understanding of the cellular components involved in IBV invasion into the cell, is839    likely to open new opportunities to develop novel therapeutic approaches.

TABREF2.text: IBV entry is low pH dependent.the low pH dependent entry of IBV is cell type specific. To this end, we increased the Cl treated cells. To examine the functional role of a low pH on IBV infectivity,

TABREF3.text: ). Thus, these results reveal that IBV enters cells via CME, but not via macropinocytosis. Whether the CavME is involved in IBV endocytosis may be cell type dependent and is controversial. To explore the involvement of CavME in IBV entry, we utilized Huh7 cell, which lacks functional caveolae (15, 60), to perform above experiment. As evidenced by high level of intracellular viral gRNA and N protein expression, efficient virus internalization and replication was observed inHuh7 cells (Fig. 5G-H), demonstrating that IBV entry is independent of caveolae. Moreover, CPZ pretreatment significantly reduced IBV gRNA internalization and N protein expression in Huh7 cells, while neither Amiloride nor Nystatin reduced the 481 internalization and replication (Fig. 5G-H), consistent with those observed in other 482cell lines. Combining above results, we conclude that IBV entry is mediated by CME, and this is not restricted to cell types.CME of IBV is dependent on dynamin1 but not Eps15.Eps15 is a regulatory protein which has been characterized by a ubiquitous and constitutive association with the AP-2 protein adapter. Microinjection of Eps15 antibody interfered with transferring and EGFR internalization (61), suggesting that Eps15 plays an important role in CME. Several reviews described previously that the expression of the C-terminal dominant negative form of Eps15-DN, which contains the AP2-binding site, could efficiently block the uptake of Sindbis virus (62).Dynamin1 is a GTPase facilitating membrane fission to generate endocytic vesicles in CME and CavME (47, 63, 64). Many reviews describe that dynamin1 is required for the internalization of various viruses, as the dynamin1-K44A, a dominant negative mutant demonstrated preciously to block virus entry (65, 66). To examine the involvement of Eps15 and dynamin1 in IBV entry, we expressed pEGFPN1, GFP-tagged Eps15-WT, Eps15-DN, dynamin1-WT, and dynamin1-DN in H1299 cells, respectively, followed by IBV infection. pEGFPN1 was expressed as the control.
